TITLE:

   - Received Maalox x1
   - Requested albuterol inhaler at bedside

   Physical Examination
   GENERAL: WDWN, mildly agitated, occasional non-productive cough,
   stating he cannot breath. Oriented x3.
   HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no
   pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma.  Mucosa mildly
   dry.
   NECK: Supple with JVP of 8 cm.
   CARDIAC: PMI located in 5th intercostal space, midclavicular line. RR,
   normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. No thrills, lifts. No S3 or S4.
   LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were
   unlabored, no accessory muscle use. + Expiratory wheezes b/l, no
   crackles or rhonchi.  Decreased breath sounds at bilateral bases,

   ABDOMEN: Obese, soft, non-tender, non-distended.
   EXTREMITIES: No c/c/e. 2+ edema in LE b/l to just above knees,
   symmetric and pitting

                             [**2200-6-1**]  07:50 PM
   WBC
   7.3
   Hct
   28.0
   Plt
    138
   Cr
   2.4
   TropT
    0.13
   Glucose
   109
   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:16.4/35.6/1.5, CK / CKMB / Troponin-T:415//
   0.13, ALT / AST:22/56, Alk Phos / T Bili:110/0.3, LDH:522 IU/L,
   Mg++:1.2
   Assessment and Plan
   59 yo M with PMH of systolic CHF, known pleural effusions, admitted
   with worsening shortness of breath and LE swelling x 1 month.
   .
   #  DYSPNEA: Primary complaint on admission.  Likely related to
   recurrent pleural effusion, bradycardia, hypoalbuminemia [**12-30**] poor
   nutrition and some element of medication noncompliance which may be
   worsening his COPD control.  No e/o of decompensated heart failure on
   exam or CXR, BNP lower than prior baseline.  Could consider ACS but no
   chest pressure. Bradycardia resolved ON w/ HR 70-80s
   - Continue Albuterol, Tiotroprium and Salmeterol-Fluticasone; start
   scheduled Albuterol
   - Supplemental oxygen
   - Consider thoracentesis for symptomatic benefit today
   .
   #  Systolic CHF: Unclear etiology, though likely some component of
   alcohol cardiomyopathy and possibly some tachy-myopathy.  No h/o
   ischemia. EF 35%. BNP > 15,000 but lower than prior admission.  JVP not
   elavated and no e/o CXR.  Pulmonary exam with diminished sounds at
   bases [**12-30**] effusions, which may be due to CHF.  LE edema likely
   multifactorial and not [**Last Name (un) 6759**] attributable to CHF
   - Held BP medications given normotensive (Hydralazine / Imdur) o/n
   can restart this AM
   - Hold Diltiazem / Metoprolol given bradycardia yesterday. But will
   reconsider restarting beta blocker (low dose) if HR continues to be
   stable.
   - Hold Lasix given mild hypovolemia
   - Daily ASA
   .
   #  CORONARIES: No prior cardiac catheterization.  No prior ischemic
   events. No plan to cath at this time.
   - ASA daily
   .
   #  PUMP: History of Systolic CHF; Ef = 30%.  NO e/o volume overload at
   this time.
   .
   #  RHYTHM: Atrial fibrillation with decreased ventricular response.
   - Hold rate controlling agents given bradycardia
   .
   #  ARF: Unclear etiology.  Worsened from prior baseline.  Appears
   intravascularly dry on exam. CXR without volume overload.  Denies any
   dsyuria.
   - FeNa 1%
   - IVF o/n and Cr trend improved slightly.
   - Will continue to trend Cr
   .
   #  Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis: With elevated lactate, low
   bicarbonate. On prior admission, resolved with fluid resuscitation.
   Some component of dehydration.  Lactate may be related to poor liver
   function.
   - Responded well to fluid resuscitate. Will trial PO today.
   - Trend lactate
   - Monitor labs
   .
   #  Alcohol Abuse: Reported h/o DTs with seizures.  Patient states
   seizures are unrelated and he gets them when he's 'hot and cold.
   description suggestive of rigors vs. seizures.  SW consult ordered
   today
   - MVI, thiamine, folate
 f/u labs
   - CIWA with Valium
   - Seizure / aspiration precautions
   .
   #  Anemia: Normocytic and similar to prior levels.  No e/o acute blood
   loss, patient refused rectal exam in ED.
   - Trend, if worsens will T&C
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation - Rate well-controlled on diltiazem and
   metoprolol. Continued aspirin. Coumadin therapy deferred due to
   patient preference and concerns regarding  medication and
   monitoring noncompliance.
   - Rate &0s, well controlled this morning
   .
   # Diabetes mellitus type II - On Metformin in [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] be contributing
   to Lactic acidosis.
   - ISS with FS QACHS
   - Hold Metformin
   .
   # Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease - Complaining of dyspnea as
   above, likely multifactorial.
   - Continue Advair, Spiriva, and Albuterol prn.
   .
   #  Hyponatremia / Hypochloremia: Suspect [**12-30**] hypovolemia and
   malnutrition from chronic alcoholism.  Calculated sodium deficit
   recommends 160cc/hr of NS x 16 hours to reach 130; will give more
   slowly given CHF
   - Continue IV NS (~75cc/hr) to replete sodium
   - Continue to monitor labs; recheck lytes
   .
   # Abdominal Pain: Patient stated pain is diffuse and chronic but
   resolved o/n.  Also with some nausea prior to admission w/ some
   sputum/clear fluid emesis this AM.
   - Zofran PRN nausea
   .
   #  Thrombocytopenia: New thrombocytopenia.  [**Month (only) 60**] represent overall poor
   hepatic function.
   - Trend, avoid medications that worsen
   .
   #  Elevated INR: Concerning for worsened hepatic function; also with
   likely some element of malnutrition.
   - Trend coagulopathy
   .
   # Recurrent left pleural effusion -  Previously evaluated for this.  On
   last admission, underwent left-sided diagnostic and therapeutic
   thoracentesis on [**2200-4-14**] with removal of 2.3L transudative fluid.
   Cytology negative for malignant cells. Attributed to chronic systolic
   CHF and medication noncompliance. Added hydralazine and isosorbide for
   better afterload reduction. Adequate room air ambulatory oxygen
   saturation prior to discharge.  Now readmitted with worsened effusion,
   dyspnea and new O2 requirement.
   - Consider thoracentesis today
   .
   # Mediastinal lymphadenopathy/pulmonary nodules -  Noted on prior
   admission, recommended follow-up CT in 3 months.
   .
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Gentle IVF/replete Mg/regular diet
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2200-6-1**] 10:34 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2200-6-1**] 10:35 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: IV Heparin
   Stress ulcer: Omeprazole 20mg Qdaily
   Pain:
   Bowels: Docusate PRN
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: Pt states there is no one he would like us to
   call
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: Call out to floor

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following information:

The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of systolic CHF, known pleural effusions, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He was admitted with worsening shortness of breath and left lower extremity (LE) swelling for one month.

The patient's current condition includes:

* Atrial fibrillation with a decreased ventricular response
* Bradycardia, which resolved with treatment
* Hypoalbuminemia and poor nutrition
* Recurrent left pleural effusion
* Chronic systolic CHF with an ejection fraction of 35%
* Normocytic anemia
* Elevated lactate and anion gap metabolic acidosis
* Hyponatremia and hypochloremia
* Thrombocytopenia and elevated INR
* Abdominal pain and nausea

The patient's medical complications include:

* Recurrent pleural effusion, which may be related to his CHF and medication noncompliance
* Atrial fibrillation, which is well-controlled with rate-controlling agents
* Anion gap metabolic acidosis, which may be related to poor liver function and dehydration
* Thrombocytopenia, which may be related to poor hepatic function and malnutrition
* Elevated INR, which may be related to worsened hepatic function and malnutrition
* Hyponatremia and hypochloremia, which may be related to hypovolemia and malnutrition

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continuing Albuterol, Tiotroprium, and Salmeterol-Fluticasone for COPD
* Supplemental oxygen
* Considering thoracentesis for symptomatic benefit
* Holding BP medications due to normotensive status
* Holding Lasix due to mild hypovolemia
* Restarting beta blocker (low dose) if HR continues to be stable
* Continuing IV NS to replete sodium
* Trending labs, including electrolytes, lactate, and coagulopathy

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is to call out to the floor for further management.

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:16.4/35.6/1.5, CK / CKMB / Troponin-T:415//
   0.13, ALT / AST:22/56, Alk Phos / T Bili:110/0.3, LDH:522 IU/L,
   Mg++:1.2
   Assessment and Plan
   59 yo M with PMH of systolic CHF, known pleural effusions, admitted
   with worsening shortness of breath and LE swelling x 1 month.
   .
   #  DYSPNEA: Primary complaint on admission.  Likely related to
   recurrent pleural effusion, bradycardia and some element of medication
   noncompliance which may be worsening his COPD control.  No e/o of
   decompensated heart failure on exam or CXR, BNP lower than prior
   baseline.  Could consider ACS but no chest pressure.
   - Continue Albuterol, Tiotroprium and Salmeterol-Fluticasone
   - Supplemental oxygen
   - Bradycardia as below
   - Consider thoracentesis in AM for symptomatic benefit
   .
   #  Systolic CHF: Unclear etiology, though likely some component of
   alcohol cardiomyopathy and possibly some tachy-myopathy.  No h/o
   ischemia.  BNP > 15,000 but lower than prior admission.  JVP not
   elavated and no e/o CXR.  Pulmonary exam with diminished sounds at
   bases [**12-30**] effusions, which may be due to CHF.  LE edema likely
   multifactorial and not [**Last Name (un) 6759**] attributable to CHF.
   - Hold BP medications given normotensive (Hydralazine / Imdur)
   - Hold Diltiazem / Metoprolol given bradycardia
   - Hold Lasix given mild hypovolemia
   - Daily ASA
   .
   #  CORONARIES: No prior cardiac catheterization.  No prior ischemic
   events.
   - ASA daily
   .
   #  PUMP: History of Systolic CHF; Ef = 30%.  NO e/o volume overload at
   this time.
   .
   #  RHYTHM: Atrial fibrillation with decreased ventricular response.
   - Hold rate controlling agents given bradycardia
   .
   #  ARF: Unclear etiology.  Worsened from prior baseline.  Appears
   intravascularly dry on exam. CXR without volume overload.  Denies any
   dsyuria.
   - UA, Ulytes
   - IVF o/n
   - Trend Cr
   .
   #  Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis: With elevated lactate, low
   bicarbonate. On prior admission, resolved with fluid resuscitation.
   Some component of dehydration.  Lactate may be related to poor liver
   function.
   - Fluid resuscitate
   - Trend lactate
   - Monitor labs
   .
   #  Alcohol Abuse: Reported h/o DTs with seizures.  Patient states
   seizures are unrelated and he gets them when he's 'hot and cold'
   - MVI, thiamine, folate
   - CIWA with Valium
   - SW consult
   - Seizure / aspiration precautions
   .
   #  Anemia: Normocytic and similar to prior levels.  No e/o acute blood
   loss, patient refused rectal exam in ED.
   - Trend, if worsens will T&C
   - Guaiac stools
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation - Rate well-controlled on diltiazem and
   metoprolol. Continued aspirin. Coumadin therapy deferred due to
   patient preference and concerns regarding  medication and
   monitoring noncompliance.
   .
   # Diabetes mellitus type II - On Metformin in [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] be contributing
   to Lactic acidosis.
   - ISS with FS QACHS
   - Hold Metformin
   .
   # Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease - Complaining of dyspnea as
   above, likely multifactorial.
   - Continue Advair, Spiriva, and Albuterol prn.
   .
   #  Hyponatremia / Hypochloremia: Suspect [**12-30**] hypovolemia and
   malnutrition from chronic alcoholism.  Calculated sodium deficit
   recommends 160cc/hr of NS x 16 hours to reach 130; will give more
   slowly given CHF
   - IVF o/n
   .
   # Abdominal Pain: Patient states pain is diffuse and chronic.  Also
   with some nausea prior to admission.
   - Zofran PRN nausea
   - Add on LFTs
   - Review prior imaging / work-up
   .
   #  Thrombocytopenia: New thrombocytopenia.  [**Month (only) 60**] represent overall poor
   hepatic function.
   - Trend, avoid medications that worsen
   .
   #  Elevated INR: Concerning for worsened hepatic function; also with
   likely some element of malnutrition.
   - Trend coagulopathy
   .
   # Recurrent left pleural effusion -  Previously evaluated for this.  On
   last admission, underwent left-sided diagnostic and therapeutic
   thoracentesis on [**2200-4-14**] with removal of 2.3L transudative fluid.
   Cytology negative for malignant cells. Attributed to chronic systolic
   CHF and medication noncompliance. Added hydralazine and isosorbide for
   better afterload reduction. Adequate room air ambulatory oxygen
   saturation prior to discharge.  Now readmitted with worsened effusion,
   dyspnea and new O2 requirement.
   - Consider thoracentesis
   .
   # Mediastinal lymphadenopathy/pulmonary nodules -  Noted on prior
   admission, recommended follow-up CT in 3 months.
   .
   FEN:  Gentle IVF / replete Mg / NPO
   .
   ACCESS: PIV
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with Heparin IV, pending troponin downward trending
   -Bowel regimen with Docusate PRN
   .
   CODE: FULL CODE (confirmed on admission)
   .
   COMM: Pt states there is nobody he would like us to call
   .
   DISPO: CCU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2200-6-1**] 10:34 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2200-6-1**] 10:35 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:

   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code

Summary:

The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of systolic CHF, known pleural effusions, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He was admitted with worsening shortness of breath and left lower extremity (LE) swelling. His primary complaint is dyspnea, likely related to recurrent pleural effusion, bradycardia, and medication noncompliance. He has atrial fibrillation with a decreased ventricular response and is on rate-controlling agents. He also has anemia, normocytic, and similar to prior levels. He has hyponatremia and hypochloremia, suspecting hypovolemia and malnutrition from chronic alcoholism. He has thrombocytopenia, elevated INR, and elevated lactate, indicating anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Potential medical complications:

1. Recurrent pleural effusion: The patient has a history of pleural effusions, and it is likely to recur. Thoracentesis may be necessary to relieve symptoms.
2. CHF decompensation: The patient has systolic CHF, and it is possible that his condition may worsen, leading to decompensation.
3. Bradycardia: The patient's bradycardia may worsen, leading to decreased cardiac output and increased risk of cardiac arrest.
4. Anion gap metabolic acidosis: The patient's anion gap metabolic acidosis may worsen, leading to further acidosis and potential organ damage.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen, leading to increased risk of bleeding.
6. Elevated INR: The patient's elevated INR may worsen, leading to increased risk of bleeding and potential organ damage.
7. Hyponatremia and hypochloremia: The patient's hyponatremia and hypochloremia may worsen, leading to further electrolyte imbalance and potential organ damage.
8. Lactic acidosis: The patient's lactic acidosis may worsen, leading to further acidosis and potential organ damage.
9. Seizures: The patient has a history of seizures, and it is possible that they may recur, especially with worsening liver function.
10. Aspiration: The patient's decreased level of consciousness and potential aspiration risk may lead to aspiration pneumonia.

Based on the patient's condition, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, electrolyte levels, and liver function. Frequent assessments of his respiratory and cardiac status are necessary to prevent complications. Additionally, the patient's medication regimen should be carefully managed to minimize the risk of interactions and adverse effects.

   59 yo M with PMH of systolic CHF, known pleural effusions, admitted
   with worsening shortness of breath and LE swelling x 1 month.
   .
   #  DYSPNEA: Primary complaint on admission.  Likely related to
   recurrent pleural effusion, bradycardia and some element of medication
   noncompliance which may be worsening his COPD control.  No e/o of
   decompensated heart failure on exam or CXR, BNP lower than prior
   baseline.  Could consider ACS but no chest pressure.
   - Continue Albuterol, Tiotroprium and Salmeterol-Fluticasone
   - Supplemental oxygen
   - Bradycardia as below
   - Consider thoracentesis in AM for symptomatic benefit
   .
   #  Systolic CHF: Unclear etiology, though likely some component of
   alcohol cardiomyopathy and possibly some tachy-myopathy.  No h/o
   ischemia.  BNP > 15,000 but lower than prior admission.  JVP not
   elavated and no e/o CXR.  Pulmonary exam with diminished sounds at
   bases [**12-30**] effusions, which may be due to CHF.  LE edema likely
   multifactorial and not [**Last Name (un) 6759**] attributable to CHF.
   - Hold BP medications given normotensive (Hydralazine / Imdur)
   - Hold Diltiazem / Metoprolol given bradycardia
   - Hold Lasix given mild hypovolemia
   - Daily ASA
   .
   #  CORONARIES: No prior cardiac catheterization.  No prior ischemic
   events.
   - ASA daily
   .
   #  PUMP: History of Systolic CHF; Ef = 30%.  NO e/o volume overload at
   this time.
   .
   #  RHYTHM: Atrial fibrillation with decreased ventricular response.
   - Hold rate controlling agents given bradycardia
   .
   #  ARF: Unclear etiology.  Worsened from prior baseline.  Appears
   intravascularly dry on exam. CXR without volume overload.  Denies any
   dsyuria.
   - UA, Ulytes
   - IVF o/n
   - Trend Cr
   .
   #  Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis: With elevated lactate, low
   bicarbonate. On prior admission, resolved with fluid resuscitation.
   Some component of dehydration.  Lactate may be related to poor liver
   function.
   - Fluid resuscitate
   - Trend lactate
   - Monitor labs
   .
   #  Alcohol Abuse: Reported h/o DTs with seizures.  Patient states
   seizures are unrelated and he gets them when he's 'hot and cold'
   - MVI, thiamine, folate
   - CIWA with Valium
   - SW consult
   - Seizure / aspiration precautions
   .
   #  Anemia: Normocytic and similar to prior levels.  No e/o acute blood
   loss, patient refused rectal exam in ED.
   - Trend, if worsens will T&C
   - Guaiac stools
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation - Rate well-controlled on diltiazem and
   metoprolol. Continued aspirin. Coumadin therapy deferred due to
   patient preference and concerns regarding  medication and
   monitoring noncompliance.
   .
   # Diabetes mellitus type II - On Metformin in [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] be contributing
   to Lactic acidosis.
   - ISS with FS QACHS
   - Hold Metformin
   .
   # Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease - Complaining of dyspnea as
   above, likely multifactorial.
   - Continue Advair, Spiriva, and Albuterol prn.
   .
   #  Hyponatremia / Hypochloremia: Suspect [**12-30**] hypovolemia and
   malnutrition from chronic alcoholism.  Calculated sodium deficit
   recommends 160cc/hr of NS x 16 hours to reach 130; will give more
   slowly given CHF
   - IVF o/n
   .
   # Abdominal Pain: Patient states pain is diffuse and chronic.  Also
   with some nausea prior to admission.
   - Zofran PRN nausea
   - Add on LFTs
   - Review prior imaging / work-up
   .
   #  Thrombocytopenia: New thrombocytopenia.  [**Month (only) 60**] represent overall poor
   hepatic function.
   - Trend, avoid medications that worsen
   .
   #  Elevated INR: Concerning for worsened hepatic function; also with
   likely some element of malnutrition.
   - Trend coagulopathy
   .
   # Recurrent left pleural effusion -  Previously evaluated for this.  On
   last admission, underwent left-sided diagnostic and therapeutic
   thoracentesis on [**2200-4-14**] with removal of 2.3L transudative fluid.
   Cytology negative for malignant cells. Attributed to chronic systolic
   CHF and medication noncompliance. Added hydralazine and isosorbide for
   better afterload reduction. Adequate room air ambulatory oxygen
   saturation prior to discharge.  Now readmitted with worsened effusion,
   dyspnea and new O2 requirement.
   - Consider thoracentesis
   .
   # Mediastinal lymphadenopathy/pulmonary nodules -  Noted on prior
   admission, recommended follow-up CT in 3 months.
   .
   FEN:  Gentle IVF / replete Mg / NPO
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of systolic CHF, known pleural effusions, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He was admitted with worsening shortness of breath and left leg swelling. The patient's primary complaint is dyspnea, which is likely related to recurrent pleural effusion, bradycardia, and medication noncompliance. He has atrial fibrillation with a decreased ventricular response and is receiving aspirin and warfarin. The patient has a history of alcohol abuse and is experiencing anion gap metabolic acidosis, possibly related to poor liver function. He also has normocytic anemia, hyponatremia, and hypochloremia, which may be related to chronic alcoholism and malnutrition.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening pleural effusion: The patient's pleural effusion is likely to worsen if not managed properly, leading to respiratory compromise and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Decompensated heart failure: The patient's systolic CHF may decompensate if not managed properly, leading to pulmonary edema, cardiogenic shock, and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's COPD and pleural effusion may lead to respiratory failure, which may require mechanical ventilation.
4. Seizures: The patient's history of seizures and alcohol abuse may increase the risk of seizures, which may be life-threatening if not managed properly.
5. Lactic acidosis: The patient's anion gap metabolic acidosis may worsen if not managed properly, leading to lactic acidosis, which may be life-threatening.
6. Coagulopathy: The patient's elevated INR and thrombocytopenia may increase the risk of bleeding complications, which may be life-threatening.
7. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state and presence of central lines may increase the risk of infection, which may be life-threatening.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's pleural effusion and manage it accordingly.
2. Optimize the patient's heart failure management, including adjusting medications and fluids as necessary.
3. Continue to manage the patient's COPD, including providing oxygen therapy and bronchodilators as necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's liver function and consider liver function tests (LFTs) to assess the patient's liver function.
5. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and consider electrolyte replacement as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's coagulation status and consider platelet transfusions as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider mechanical ventilation if necessary.
8. Consider consulting a specialist, such as a pulmonologist or a cardiologist, to assist with the patient's management.
9. Consider performing a thoracentesis to drain the patient's pleural effusion and relieve respiratory compromise.
10. Consider performing a liver biopsy to assess the patient's liver function and determine the cause of his liver dysfunction.

   ischemia.  BNP > 15,000 but lower than prior admission.  JVP not
   elavated and no e/o CXR.  Pulmonary exam with diminished sounds at
   bases [**12-30**] effusions, which may be due to CHF.  LE edema likely
   multifactorial and not [**Last Name (un) 6759**] attributable to CHF.
   - Hold BP medications given normotensive (Hydralazine / Imdur)
   - Hold Diltiazem / Metoprolol given bradycardia
   - Hold Lasix given mild hypovolemia
   - Daily ASA
   .
   #  CORONARIES: No prior cardiac catheterization.  No prior ischemic
   events.
   - ASA daily
   .
   #  PUMP: History of Systolic CHF; Ef = 30%.  NO e/o volume overload at
   this time.
   .
   #  RHYTHM: Atrial fibrillation with decreased ventricular response.
   - Hold rate controlling agents given bradycardia
   .
   #  ARF: Unclear etiology.  Worsened from prior baseline.  Appears
   intravascularly dry on exam. CXR without volume overload.  Denies any
   dsyuria.
   - UA, Ulytes
   - IVF o/n
   - Trend Cr
   .
   #  Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis: With elevated lactate, low
   bicarbonate. On prior admission, resolved with fluid resuscitation.
   Some component of dehydration.  Lactate may be related to poor liver
   function.
   - Fluid resuscitate
   - Trend lactate
   - Monitor labs
   .
   #  Alcohol Abuse: Reported h/o DTs with seizures.  Patient states
   seizures are unrelated and he gets them when he's 'hot and cold'
   - MVI, thiamine, folate
   - CIWA with Valium
   - SW consult
   - Seizure / aspiration precautions
   .
   #  Anemia: Normocytic and similar to prior levels.  No e/o acute blood
   loss, patient refused rectal exam in ED.
   - Trend, if worsens will T&C
   - Guaiac stools
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation - Rate well-controlled on diltiazem and
   metoprolol. Continued aspirin. Coumadin therapy deferred due to
   patient preference and concerns regarding  medication and
   monitoring noncompliance.
   .
   # Diabetes mellitus type II - On Metformin in [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] be contributing
   to Lactic acidosis.
   - ISS with FS QACHS
   - Hold Metformin
   .
   # Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease - Complaining of dyspnea as
   above, likely multifactorial.
   - Continue Advair, Spiriva, and Albuterol prn.
   .
   #  Hyponatremia / Hypochloremia: Suspect [**12-30**] hypovolemia and
   malnutrition from chronic alcoholism.  Calculated sodium deficit
   recommends 160cc/hr of NS x 16 hours to reach 130; will give more
   slowly given CHF
   - IVF o/n
   .
   # Abdominal Pain: Patient states pain is diffuse and chronic.  Also
   with some nausea prior to admission.
   - Zofran PRN nausea
   - Add on LFTs
   - Review prior imaging / work-up
   .
   #  Thrombocytopenia: New thrombocytopenia.  [**Month (only) 60**] represent overall poor
   hepatic function.
   - Trend, avoid medications that worsen
   .
   #  Elevated INR: Concerning for worsened hepatic function; also with
   likely some element of malnutrition.
   - Trend coagulopathy
   .
   # Recurrent left pleural effusion -  Previously evaluated for this.  On
   last admission, underwent left-sided diagnostic and therapeutic
   thoracentesis on [**2200-4-14**] with removal of 2.3L transudative fluid.
   Cytology negative for malignant cells. Attributed to chronic systolic
   CHF and medication noncompliance. Added hydralazine and isosorbide for
   better afterload reduction. Adequate room air ambulatory oxygen
   saturation prior to discharge.  Now readmitted with worsened effusion,
   dyspnea and new O2 requirement.
   - Consider thoracentesis
   .
   # Mediastinal lymphadenopathy/pulmonary nodules -  Noted on prior
   admission, recommended follow-up CT in 3 months.
   .
   FEN:  Gentle IVF / replete Mg / NPO

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of systolic CHF, known pleural effusions, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He was admitted with worsening shortness of breath and left leg swelling for one month.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.6C (97.9F)
* Heart rate: 70 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 127/73 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 95%
* Atrial fibrillation with a decreased ventricular response

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General: Worn, mildly agitated, occasional non-productive cough, stating he cannot breathe
* HEENT: Normal, no abnormalities
* Neck: Supple, jugular venous pressure (JVP) of 8 cm
* Cardiac: Precordial murmurs (PMI) located in the 5th intercostal space, midclavicular line, normal S1 and S2 sounds, no murmurs or thrills
* Lungs: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis, or kyphosis, respire unlabored, no accessory muscle use, mild expiratory wheezes, decreased breath sounds at bilateral bases
* Abdomen: Obese, soft, non-tender, non-distended
* Extremities: No clubbing, 2+ edema in the lower extremities (LE) bilaterally to just above the knees, symmetric
* Skin: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 7.3
* Hematocrit (Hct): 28.0
* Platelet count (Plt): 138
* Creatinine (Cr): 2.4
* Troponin-T: 0.13
* Glucose: 109
* Other lab results: see below

The patient's medications include:

* Albuterol, tiotropium, and salmeterol-fluticasone for COPD
* Heparin for DVT prophylaxis
* Omeprazole for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Metformin for diabetes mellitus type II (held due to lactic acidosis concerns)
* Diltiazem and metoprolol for CHF (held due to bradycardia)

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to COPD exacerbation or pleural effusion
* Cardiac decompensation due to CHF or atrial fibrillation
* Lactic acidosis due to Metformin therapy or underlying liver dysfunction
* Thrombocytopenia due to liver dysfunction or medication side effects
* Anion gap metabolic acidosis due to dehydration or liver dysfunction
* Hyponatremia and hypochloremia due to hypovolemia and malnutrition
* Recurrent pleural effusion due to CHF or medication noncompliance
* Mediastinal lymphadenopathy/pulmonary nodules due to underlying malignancy

The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management to prevent these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 59-year-old male admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a diagnosis of systolic chronic heart failure (CHF), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and atrial fibrillation (AFIB). He has a history of transudative pleural effusions and was previously evaluated for recurrent left pleural effusions. He is currently experiencing dyspnea, hypoxia, and acute on chronic CHF, requiring mechanical ventilation and diuresis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a history of alcohol abuse and is at risk for developing sepsis due to his compromised immune system.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's chronic COPD and acute on chronic CHF make him prone to respiratory failure, which could worsen his hypoxia.
3. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's AFIB and CHF increase his risk of cardiac arrest, especially if not properly managed.
4. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's hypovolemia, fluid overload, and decreased cardiac output put him at risk for AKI.
5. Hepatic Dysfunction: The patient's history of alcohol abuse and potential liver disease make him susceptible to hepatic dysfunction, which could worsen his coagulopathy and electrolyte imbalances.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's new thrombocytopenia could be a sign of worsening hepatic function or a side effect of medications.
7. Malnutrition: The patient's history of chronic illness and poor appetite put him at risk for malnutrition, which could worsen his overall health.
8. Pulmonary Embolism (PE): The patient's history of COPD and AFIB make him prone to developing PE, which could worsen his hypoxia and respiratory failure.
9. Infection: The patient's compromised immune system and history of alcohol abuse make him susceptible to infections, which could worsen his overall condition.

These potential complications highlight the need for close monitoring and aggressive management of the patient's underlying conditions to prevent further deterioration.

   Assessment and Plan
 .H/O HEART FAILURE (CHF), SYSTOLIC, CHRONIC
 .H/O CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD, BRONCHITIS,
   EMPHYSEMA) WITH ACUTE EXACERBATION
 .H/O ATRIAL FIBRILLATION (AFIB)
 .H/O ALCOHOL ABUSE
   59 yo M with PMH of systolic CHF, hx of transudative pleural effusions,
   admitted with bradycardia and acute on chronic CHF initially managed
   with fluid resulting in worsening heart failure transferred to MICU for
   hypoxia.
   .
   # DYSPNEA/HYPOXIA: Physical exam on presentation to CCU interpreted as
   intravascular depletion b/c no JVP and no signs of pulm vasc
   congestion. That said, multiple other findings pointing to acute on
   chronic CHF. Failure of initial mgt with fluid resuscitation (2L)
   supports this as evidenced by worsened CXR and oxygen requirement.
   Also evidence of PNA on CXR.
   - Continue Albuterol, Ipratropium and Salmeterol-Fluticasone
   - If worsening resp status will need to intubate.
   - diuresis with lasix bolus + drip goal out 2L+ per day.
   - CAP: start ceftriaxone, azithromycin and vanco (given hx of MRSA).
   .
   # Systolic CHF: Unclear etiology, though likely some component of
   alcohol cardiomyopathy and possibly some tachy-myopathy per cards. No
   h/o ischemia. BNP > 15,000, that it is somewhat lower than prior
   admissions is likely of little significance.
   - restart afterload reduction with hydralazine (unclear why he is not
   on an [**Name (NI) **], no allergy listed); hold long acting nitrate
   - Metoprolol restarted for rate control and improved diastolic filling
   time
   - diuresis as above  (-2L goal)
   .
   # Alcohol Abuse: Reported h/o DTs with seizures. ETOH on admission 205
   - MVI, thiamine, folate; check B12
   - CIWA with Valium
   - SW consult
   - Seizure / aspiration precautions
   # Recurrent left pleural effusion - Previously evaluated for this. On
   last admission, underwent left-sided diagnostic and therapeutic
   thoracentesis on [**2200-4-14**] with removal of 2.3L transudative fluid.
   Cytology negative for malignant cells. Attributed to chronic systolic
   CHF and medication noncompliance. Added hydralazine and isosorbide for
   better afterload reduction. Adequate room air ambulatory oxygen
   saturation prior to discharge. Now readmitted with worsened effusion,
   dyspnea and new O2 requirement.
   - Continue diuresis
   .
   # CORONARIES: No prior cardiac catheterization. No prior ischemic
   events.
   - ASA daily (DMII)
   .
   # RHYTHM: Atrial fibrillation initially with decreased ventricular
   response, now HR in 80-90 range.
   - continue holding dilt, restarted metoprolol
   - no coumadin per previously expressed pt preference, continue ASA 325
   daily
   .
   # ARF: Attributed to hypovolemia on admission; more likely to poor
   forward flow in setting of fluid overload; may have been exacerbated by
   bradycardia. Improving. Continue to monitor.
   .
   # Anemia: Normocytic and similar to prior levels. No e/o acute blood
   loss, patient refused rectal exam in ED.
   - Trend, if worsens will T&C
   - Guaiac stools
   .
   # Diabetes mellitus type II
   - ISS with FS QACHS
   - Hold Metformin
   .
   # Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease - Complaining of dyspnea as
   above, likely multifactorial.
   - Continue Advair, and Albuterol prn. Ipratrop over Spiriva as inpt
   .
   # Hyponatremia / Hypochloremia: Beer potomania? Could also be from poor
   forward flow in setting of acute on chronic CHF or liver dz;
   hypovolemic hyponatremia.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: New thrombocytopenia. [**Month (only) 60**] represent overall poor
   hepatic function.
   - Trend, avoid medications that worsen
   .
   # Elevated INR: Concerning for worsened hepatic function; also with
   likely some element of malnutrition.
   - Trend coagulopathy
   .
   # Mediastinal lymphadenopathy/pulmonary nodules - Noted on prior
   admission, recommended follow-up CT in 3 months.
   .
   FEN: Gentle IVF / replete Mg / NPO
   .
   ACCESS: PIV
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with SQH, pending troponin downward trending
   -Bowel regimen with Docusate PRN
   CODE: FULL CODE (confirmed on admission)
   COMM: Pt states there is nobody he would like us to call
   DISPO: ICU
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO
   Glycemic Control:

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information:

The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of systolic chronic heart failure (CHF), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation (AF), and alcohol abuse. He was admitted to the ICU with bradycardia and acute on chronic CHF, initially managed with fluid resuscitation, which worsened his heart failure.

The patient has a 24-hour event where the RN was unable to place a foley catheter, and Urology consultation is needed to help with foley placement. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.1C (98.8F), heart rate of 95 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 124/79 mmHg.

The patient has a diagnosis of acute on chronic CHF, with a B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) level of >15,000. He is being treated with diuretics, vasodilators, and rate control medications. The patient also has a history of recurrent left pleural effusion and is being treated with diuretics and oxygen therapy.

The patient has several laboratory results that are abnormal, including:

* Elevated troponin-T levels, indicating possible myocardial infarction or injury
* Thrombocytopenia, with a platelet count of 95 K/L
* Elevated liver enzymes, including AST, ALT, and LDH
* Hyponatremia and hypochloremia, possibly due to poor forward flow in setting of acute on chronic CHF or liver disease
* Elevated INR, indicating possible worsened hepatic function or malnutrition

The patient is being treated with antibiotics for possible pneumonia, and his respiratory status is stable, with a SpO2 of 93%. He is also being treated for alcohol withdrawal and has a history of seizures.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Worsening heart failure, leading to cardiogenic shock
* Respiratory failure, requiring intubation
* Sepsis, due to the patient's immunocompromised state
* Gastrointestinal bleeding, due to the patient's history of liver disease and use of anticoagulation therapy
* Thrombocytopenia, leading to bleeding complications
* Worsened hepatic function, leading to coagulopathy and increased risk of bleeding

Overall, the patient's condition is complex, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent complications and improve his outcomes.

   Assessment and Plan
 .H/O HEART FAILURE (CHF), SYSTOLIC, CHRONIC
 .H/O CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD, BRONCHITIS,
   EMPHYSEMA) WITH ACUTE EXACERBATION
 .H/O ATRIAL FIBRILLATION (AFIB)
 .H/O ALCOHOL ABUSE
   59 yo M with PMH of systolic CHF, hx of transudative pleural effusions,
   admitted with bradycardia and acute on chronic CHF initially managed
   with fluid resulting in worsening heart failure transferred to MICU for
   hypoxia.
   .
   # DYSPNEA/HYPOXIA: Physical exam on presentation to CCU interpreted as
   intravascular depletion b/c no JVP and no signs of pulm vasc
   congestion. That said, multiple other findings pointing to acute on
   chronic CHF. Failure of initial mgt with fluid resuscitation (2L)
   supports this as evidenced by worsened CXR and oxygen requirement.
   Also evidence of PNA on CXR.
   - Continue Albuterol, Ipratropium and Salmeterol-Fluticasone
   - If worsening resp status will need to intubate.
   - diuresis with lasix bolus + drip goal out 2L+ per day.
   - Consider thoracentesis for symptomatic benefit if little yield from
   diuresis
   .
   # Systolic CHF: Unclear etiology, though likely some component of
   alcohol cardiomyopathy and possibly some tachy-myopathy per cards. No
   h/o ischemia. BNP > 15,000, that it is somewhat lower than prior
   admissions is likely of little significance.
   - restart afterload reduction with hydralazine (unclear why he is not
   on an [**Name (NI) **], no allergy listed); hold long acting nitrate
   - Metoprolol restarted for rate control and improved diastolic filling
   time
   - diuresis as above
   .
   # Alcohol Abuse: Reported h/o DTs with seizures. ETOH on admission 205
   - MVI, thiamine, folate; check B12
   - CIWA with Valium
   - SW consult
   - Seizure / aspiration precautions
   # Recurrent left pleural effusion - Previously evaluated for this. On
   last admission, underwent left-sided diagnostic and therapeutic
   thoracentesis on [**2200-4-14**] with removal of 2.3L transudative fluid.
   Cytology negative for malignant cells. Attributed to chronic systolic
   CHF and medication noncompliance. Added hydralazine and isosorbide for
   better afterload reduction. Adequate room air ambulatory oxygen
   saturation prior to discharge. Now readmitted with worsened effusion,
   dyspnea and new O2 requirement.
   - Consider thoracentesis as above
   .
   # CORONARIES: No prior cardiac catheterization. No prior ischemic
   events.
   - ASA daily (DMII)
   .
   # RHYTHM: Atrial fibrillation initially with decreased ventricular
   response, now HR in 80-90 range.
   - continue holding dilt, restarted metoprolol
   - no coumadin per previously expressed pt preference, continue ASA 325
   daily
   .
   # ARF: Attributed to hypovolemia on admission; more likely to poor
   forward flow in setting of fluid overload; may have been exacerbated by
   bradycardia. Improving. Continue to monitor.
   .
   # Anemia: Normocytic and similar to prior levels. No e/o acute blood
   loss, patient refused rectal exam in ED.
   - Trend, if worsens will T&C
   - Guaiac stools
   .
   # Diabetes mellitus type II
   - ISS with FS QACHS
   - Hold Metformin
   .
   # Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease - Complaining of dyspnea as
   above, likely multifactorial.
   - Continue Advair, and Albuterol prn. Ipratrop over Spiriva as inpt
   .
   # Hyponatremia / Hypochloremia: Beer potomania? Could also be from poor
   forward flow in setting of acute on chronic CHF or liver dz.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: New thrombocytopenia. [**Month (only) 60**] represent overall poor
   hepatic function.
   - Trend, avoid medications that worsen
   .
   # Elevated INR: Concerning for worsened hepatic function; also with
   likely some element of malnutrition.
   - Trend coagulopathy
   .
   # Mediastinal lymphadenopathy/pulmonary nodules - Noted on prior
   admission, recommended follow-up CT in 3 months.
   .
   FEN: Gentle IVF / replete Mg / NPO
   .
   ACCESS: PIV
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with SQH, pending troponin downward trending
   -Bowel regimen with Docusate PRN
   CODE: FULL CODE (confirmed on admission)
   COMM: Pt states there is nobody he would like us to call
   DISPO: ICU
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Summary:

The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation, and alcohol abuse. He was admitted to the ICU with acute exacerbation of chronic heart failure, acute on chronic COPD, and acute kidney injury. He has a 24-hour history of failed Foley catheter placement, requiring urology consultation. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35C, heart rate of 95 bpm, and blood pressure of 124/79 mmHg. His oxygen saturation is 93%, and he is on non-rebreather oxygen therapy. He has a history of transudative pleural effusions and has undergone thoracentesis in the past.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening of heart failure: The patient's heart failure is acute on chronic, and he is already requiring oxygen therapy. Further exacerbation of his heart failure could lead to worsening respiratory status, increased risk of arrhythmias, and decreased cardiac output.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic COPD and acute exacerbation increase his risk of respiratory failure. He is already requiring oxygen therapy, and further deterioration could lead to the need for intubation.
3. Sepsis: The patient's history of alcohol abuse and recent hospitalization increase his risk of developing sepsis. His laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count and C-reactive protein, which may indicate an inflammatory response.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, which may increase his risk of bleeding. His liver function tests are also abnormal, which could contribute to his thrombocytopenia.
5. Hyponatremia and hypochloremia: The patient's electrolyte imbalance could be due to beer potomania, poor forward flow in setting of acute on chronic CHF, or liver disease. Further monitoring and correction of electrolyte imbalance are necessary.
6. Infection: The patient's history of transudative pleural effusions and recent hospitalization increase his risk of developing infection. His laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count and C-reactive protein, which may indicate an inflammatory response.
7. Renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen if he continues to experience hypovolemia, hypotension, or decreased cardiac output. Further monitoring of his renal function is necessary.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and respiratory status closely.
2. Consider consulting urology to assist with Foley catheter placement.
3. Continue to manage the patient's heart failure with diuresis, afterload reduction, and rate control.
4. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider intubation if necessary.
5. Consider consulting infectious disease to evaluate the patient's risk of sepsis.
6. Monitor the patient's platelet count and liver function tests closely to assess the severity of his thrombocytopenia and liver dysfunction.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte imbalance and correct as necessary.
8. Consider consulting gastroenterology to evaluate the patient's risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
9. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and consider consulting nephrology if necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of systolic chronic heart failure (CHF), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation (AF), and alcohol abuse. He is currently admitted to the ICU with acute exacerbation of CHF, hypoxia, and left pleural effusion.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35C, heart rate of 95 beats per minute, blood pressure of 124/79 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 93%. His respiratory support includes non-rebreather oxygen therapy, and he is receiving albuterol, ipratropium, and salmeterol-fluticasone.

The patient's physical examination is significant for decreased breath sounds on the left side with diffuse rhonchi, and he has 1+ edema in his lower extremities. His laboratory results show mild anemia, normocytic, and similar to prior levels, with a hemoglobin level of 95 g/L. His liver function tests (LFTs) are elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 55 IU/L and an alkaline phosphatase (ALP) level of 127 IU/L. His troponin level is elevated at 0.13 ng/mL, and his creatine kinase (CK) level is elevated at 216 IU/L.

The patient's medical history is significant for recurrent left pleural effusion, which was previously attributed to chronic systolic CHF and medication noncompliance. He has also had a history of atrial fibrillation, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and alcohol abuse.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue albuterol, ipratropium, and salmeterol-fluticasone for respiratory support
* Diuresis with lasix bolus and drip, goal out 2L+ per day
* Consider thoracentesis for symptomatic benefit if little yield from diuresis
* Restart hydralazine for afterload reduction
* Restart metoprolol for rate control and improved diastolic filling time
* Continue ASA daily for coronary artery disease
* Monitor for anemia and trend if worsens
* Hold metformin for diabetes mellitus type II
* Continue Advair and albuterol prn for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
* Trend coagulopathy and avoid medications that worsen it
* Monitor for mediastinal lymphadenopathy/pulmonary nodules

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* Worsening of heart failure leading to pulmonary edema and respiratory failure
* Development of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Increased risk of thromboembolic events due to atrial fibrillation and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
* Increased risk of gastrointestinal bleeding due to stress ulcer and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
* Increased risk of sepsis due to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and liver dysfunction
* Development of acute kidney injury (AKI) due to hypovolemia and chronic kidney disease
* Development of liver failure due to chronic liver disease and malnutrition.

 .H/O HEART FAILURE (CHF), SYSTOLIC, CHRONIC

   59 yo M with PMH of systolic CHF, hx of transudative pleural effusions,
   admitted with bradycardia and acute on chronic CHF initially managed
   with fluid resulting in worsening heart failure transferred to MICU for
   hypoxia.
   .
   # DYSPNEA/HYPOXIA: Physical exam on presentation to CCU interpreted as
   intravascular depletion b/c no JVP and no signs of pulm vasc
   congestion. That said, multiple other findings pointing to acute on
   chronic CHF. Failure of initial mgt with fluid resuscitation (2L)
   supports this as evidenced by worsened CXR and oxygen requirement.
   - Continue Albuterol, Ipratropium and Salmeterol-Fluticasone
   - NRB, if desats will consider NIPPV, goal is to wean as diuresis
   permits
   - diuresis with lasix bolus + drip goal out 2L+ per day.
   - Consider thoracentesis for symptomatic benefit if little yield from
   diuresis
   .
   # Systolic CHF: Unclear etiology, though likely some component of
   alcohol cardiomyopathy and possibly some tachy-myopathy per cards. No
   h/o ischemia. BNP > 15,000, that it is somewhat lower than prior
   admissions is likely of little significance.
   - restart afterload reduction with hydralazine (unclear why he is not
   on an [**Name (NI) **], no allergy listed); hold long acting nitrate
   - Metoprolol restarted for rate control and improved diastolic filling
   time
   - diuresis as above
   .
   # Alcohol Abuse: Reported h/o DTs with seizures. ETOH on admission 205
   - MVI, thiamine, folate; check B12
   - CIWA with Valium
   - SW consult
   - Seizure / aspiration precautions
   # Recurrent left pleural effusion - Previously evaluated for this. On
   last admission, underwent left-sided diagnostic and therapeutic
   thoracentesis on [**2200-4-14**] with removal of 2.3L transudative fluid.
   Cytology negative for malignant cells. Attributed to chronic systolic
   CHF and medication noncompliance. Added hydralazine and isosorbide for
   better afterload reduction. Adequate room air ambulatory oxygen
   saturation prior to discharge. Now readmitted with worsened effusion,
   dyspnea and new O2 requirement.
   - Consider thoracentesis as above
   .
   # CORONARIES: No prior cardiac catheterization. No prior ischemic
   events.
   - ASA daily (DMII)
   .
   # RHYTHM: Atrial fibrillation initially with decreased ventricular
   response, now HR in 80-90 range.
   - continue holding dilt, restarted metoprolol
   - no coumadin per previously expressed pt preference, continue ASA 325
   daily
   .
   # ARF: Attributed to hypovolemia on admission; more likely to poor
   forward flow in setting of fluid overload; may have been exacerbated by
   bradycardia. Improving. Continue to monitor.
   .
   # Anemia: Normocytic and similar to prior levels. No e/o acute blood
   loss, patient refused rectal exam in ED.
   - Trend, if worsens will T&C
   - Guaiac stools
   .
   # Diabetes mellitus type II
   - ISS with FS QACHS
   - Hold Metformin
   .
   # Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease - Complaining of dyspnea as
   above, likely multifactorial.
   - Continue Advair, and Albuterol prn. Ipratrop over Spiriva as inpt
   .
   # Hyponatremia / Hypochloremia: Beer potomania? Could also be from poor
   forward flow in setting of acute on chronic CHF or liver dz.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: New thrombocytopenia. [**Month (only) 60**] represent overall poor
   hepatic function.
   - Trend, avoid medications that worsen
   .
   # Elevated INR: Concerning for worsened hepatic function; also with
   likely some element of malnutrition.
   - Trend coagulopathy
   .
   # Mediastinal lymphadenopathy/pulmonary nodules - Noted on prior
   admission, recommended follow-up CT in 3 months.
   .
   FEN: Gentle IVF / replete Mg / NPO
   .
   ACCESS: PIV
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with SQH, pending troponin downward trending
   -Bowel regimen with Docusate PRN

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of systolic chronic heart failure (CHF), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation (AFib), and alcohol abuse. He was admitted with bradycardia and acute on chronic CHF, which was initially managed with fluid resuscitation, but this worsened his condition.

The patient is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) and is being treated for:

1. Systolic CHF: The patient is being managed with diuresis, afterload reduction with hydralazine, and rate control with metoprolol.
2. Acute on chronic CHF: The patient's condition is attributed to chronic systolic CHF and medication noncompliance.
3. Recurrent left pleural effusion: The patient has a history of transudative pleural effusions and is being considered for thoracentesis.
4. Coronary artery disease: The patient has no prior cardiac catheterization and no prior ischemic events.
5. Atrial fibrillation: The patient is being managed with rate control with metoprolol and warfarin is being held due to the patient's preference.
6. Acute kidney injury (ARF): The patient's ARF is attributed to hypovolemia on admission and is improving.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia is normocytic and is being monitored.
8. Diabetes mellitus type II: The patient is being managed with insulin and metformin is being held.
9. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD): The patient is being managed with bronchodilators and oxygen therapy.
10. Hyponatremia and hypochloremia: The patient's electrolyte imbalance is attributed to beer potomania, poor forward flow in setting of acute on chronic CHF, or liver disease.
11. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is new and is being monitored.
12. Elevated INR: The patient's elevated INR is concerning for worsened hepatic function and is being trended.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Worsening of CHF: The patient's condition can worsen if his fluid overload is not managed properly.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's COPD can worsen if his oxygen therapy is not adequate.
3. Sepsis: The patient's catheter and lines can increase his risk of sepsis.
4. Bleeding: The patient's thrombocytopenia and elevated INR can increase his risk of bleeding.
5. Liver dysfunction: The patient's hyponatremia and hypochloremia can indicate liver dysfunction.
6. Malnutrition: The patient's anemia and elevated INR can indicate malnutrition.
7. Infection: The patient's catheter and lines can increase his risk of infection.

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's condition and adjusting his treatment plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of systolic CHF, acute on chronic CHF, and CAP. He was intubated due to worsening respiratory status and is currently on invasive ventilation with a PEEP of 10 and FiO2 of 50%. He has a history of systolic CHF, transudative pleural effusions, and alcohol abuse.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Worsening heart failure: The patient's CHF exacerbation can lead to further cardiac compromise, decreased cardiac output, and increased mortality.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is already compromised, and further deterioration can lead to respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation, and potentially even extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
3. Sepsis: The patient has a diagnosis of CAP, which can lead to sepsis, particularly with the presence of multi-drug resistant bacteria (MRSA).
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia can increase the risk of bleeding complications, particularly with invasive procedures or trauma.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient's elevated INR can increase the risk of bleeding complications and worsen hepatic function.
6. Malnutrition: The patient's malnutrition can exacerbate his underlying conditions and increase the risk of complications.
7. Hyponatremia and hypochloremia: The patient's electrolyte imbalances can lead to complications such as seizures, cardiac arrhythmias, and respiratory failure.
8. ARF: The patient's acute kidney injury (AKI) can progress to chronic kidney disease (CKD) if not managed promptly and effectively.
9. Anemia: The patient's anemia can worsen his underlying conditions and increase the risk of complications.
10. DVT: The patient's history of DVT and the presence of central lines increase his risk of developing further thrombotic complications.

To mitigate these potential complications, the patient should receive close monitoring and management, including:

1. Aggressive fluid management to prevent fluid overload and worsening heart failure.
2. Optimal antibiotic therapy for CAP and sepsis.
3. Blood transfusions to manage anemia and thrombocytopenia.
4. Electrolyte management to prevent hyponatremia and hypochloremia.
5. Close monitoring of renal function to prevent progression to CKD.
6. Nutritional support to manage malnutrition and promote recovery.
7. Stress ulcer prophylaxis to prevent gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. VAP prophylaxis to prevent ventilator-associated pneumonia.
9. DVT prophylaxis to prevent further thrombotic complications.
10. Close communication with the patient's primary care physician and other healthcare providers to ensure optimal management and coordination of care.

The patient also has a history of atrial fibrillation (AFIB) and alcohol abuse.

The patient's medical history includes chronic heart failure, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, bronchitis, and emphysema with acute exacerbation, atrial fibrillation, and alcohol abuse.

The patient's current medications include:

* Heparin sodium (prophylaxis)

* Azithromycin

The patient's plan includes:

* Invasive ventilation

* Midazolam (Versed)
* Fentanyl

* Prophylaxis (DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP)

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Pneumonia and related respiratory complications

* Acute kidney injury due to sepsis and related electrolyte imbalances
* Hepatic dysfunction due to sepsis and related liver enzyme elevations

* Neurological complications due to sepsis and related changes in mental status
* Infection-related sepsis and related multi-organ dysfunction

It is essential to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status closely to prevent and manage these potential complications.

   .

   - CXR today basically unchanged from yesterday

   - pt not on coumadin per personal preference
   .

   - consider giving pt some gentle fluids to try to cause increase in UOP

2. Sepsis: The patient has a diagnosis of CAP and is receiving antibiotics, but there is a risk of sepsis developing, particularly with the low WBC count.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient has systolic CHF and is receiving hydralazine and metoprolol. There is a risk of further cardiac deterioration, and the patient may require more aggressive cardiac support.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a low platelet count, which may be related to poor hepatic function or malnutrition. There is a risk of bleeding, particularly with invasive procedures.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient has an elevated INR, which may be related to worsened hepatic function or malnutrition. There is a risk of bleeding or thrombosis.
6. Anemia: The patient has a low Hct, which may be related to chronic blood loss or malnutrition. There is a risk of further anemia and potential bleeding.
7. Hyponatremia and hypochloremia: The patient has hyponatremia and hypochloremia, which may be related to beer potomania, poor forward flow in the setting of acute on chronic CHF, or liver disease. There is a risk of further electrolyte imbalance and potential complications.
8. Liver dysfunction: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, which may be related to liver disease or malnutrition. There is a risk of further liver dysfunction and potential complications.
9. Malnutrition: The patient has a low albumin level, which may be related to malnutrition or chronic illness. There is a risk of further malnutrition and potential complications.
10. Infection: The patient has a diagnosis of CAP and is receiving antibiotics, but there is a risk of further infection, particularly with the low WBC count.

Overall, the patient is at risk of multiple complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), admitted with bradycardia and acute on chronic CHF. He was initially managed with fluid, which worsened his heart failure, and was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) for hypoxia. He was intubated yesterday due to worsening respiratory status. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), diabetes mellitus type II, and recurrent left pleural effusion. He is currently on mechanical ventilation, and his condition is stable.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk of developing sepsis due to his pneumonia and the presence of an invasive device (arterial line and central line).
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is still unstable, and he may require further interventions to maintain adequate oxygenation.
3. Cardiac Complications: The patient's CHF is likely to worsen, and he may require further management with medications and fluids.
4. Infection: The patient has a central line and an arterial line, which increases his risk of developing a central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI) or an arterial line-associated infection.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen, and he may require platelet transfusions to prevent bleeding complications.
6. Liver Dysfunction: The patient's liver function is likely to be impaired, and he may require further management with medications and fluids to prevent further deterioration.
7. Renal Failure: The patient's renal function is at risk of worsening due to his CHF and the presence of an invasive device.
8. Nutritional Deficiencies: The patient's nutritional status is at risk of worsening due to his inability to eat and his underlying medical conditions.
9. Anxiety and Depression: The patient is at risk of developing anxiety and depression due to his underlying medical conditions and the uncertainty of his condition.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his mechanical ventilation settings as needed.
2. Continue to manage the patient's CHF with medications and fluids, and consider further interventions if necessary.
3. Monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust his insulin regimen as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's liver function and adjust his medications and fluids accordingly.
5. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his fluid management accordingly.
6. Consider further interventions to improve the patient's nutritional status, such as total parenteral nutrition (TPN) or enteral nutrition.
7. Consider referring the patient to a psychiatrist or psychologist to manage his anxiety and depression.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's central line and arterial line for signs of infection, and consider removing them if necessary.
9. Consider further interventions to prevent further complications, such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) prophylaxis and stress ulcer prophylaxis.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation (AF), and alcohol abuse.
* He was admitted with bradycardia and acute on chronic CHF, and was intubated due to worsening respiratory status.
* He is currently on mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 10 and FiO2 of 40%.
* He has a central venous catheter (CVC), an arterial line, and a multi-lumen catheter.

**Potential Complications:**

1. **Respiratory Complications:**
	* Pneumonia (CAP) may worsen, leading to respiratory failure or ARDS.
	* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) is a concern due to the prolonged use of mechanical ventilation.
2. **Cardiovascular Complications:**
	* Atrial fibrillation (AF) may worsen, leading to cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.
	* Cardiomyopathy may progress, leading to decreased cardiac function and increased risk of cardiac arrest.
3. **Renal Complications:**
	* Acute kidney injury (ARF) is a concern due to the patient's history of CHF and COPD.
	* Hypovolemia may worsen, leading to decreased renal perfusion and increased risk of ARF.
4. **Coagulopathy Complications:**
	* The patient's elevated INR and thrombocytopenia may worsen, leading to bleeding or thrombosis.
	* The patient's poor hepatic function may contribute to the coagulopathy.
5. **Nutritional Complications:**
	* The patient's history of malnutrition may worsen, leading to decreased immune function and increased risk of infections.
	* Hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia may occur due to the patient's diabetes mellitus type II.
6. **Infection Complications:**
	* The patient's history of MRSA may worsen, leading to increased risk of infection.
	* The patient's prolonged use of antibiotics may lead to antibiotic-resistant infections.

**Plan:**

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status, cardiac function, and renal function.
* Adjust medications as needed to manage atrial fibrillation, cardiomyopathy, and coagulopathy.
* Monitor the patient's nutritional status and provide enteral nutrition as needed.
* Continue to provide antibiotic therapy for pneumonia and monitor for signs of infection.
* Consider stress ulcer prophylaxis and DVT prophylaxis as needed.
* Monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust insulin therapy as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male with a complex medical history, including systolic chronic heart failure, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, atrial fibrillation, and a history of alcohol abuse. The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to worsening respiratory status and hypoxia.

The patient's current vital signs include:

* Temperature: 37C (98.6F)
* Heart rate: 100 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 112/67 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 13 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 98%
* Atrial fibrillation (AF) is present, with an elevated heart rate.

The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) of 41 cmH2O, plateau pressure of 21 cmH2O, and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. The patient's partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) is 410 mmHg, and the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) is 41 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 6.7 x 109/L
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 8.0 g/dL
* Platelet count (PLT): 84 x 109/L
* Creatinine (Cr): 1.7 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 23 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.0 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.5 g/dL
* Liver function tests (LFTs) show elevated levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT), aspartate aminotransferase (AST), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH).

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Atrial fibrillation (AF)
* Respiratory failure, acute (not acute respiratory distress syndrome [ARDS])
* Cardiomyopathy, other
* Anemia, other
* Pneumonia, bacterial, community-acquired (CAP)
* Chronic heart failure (CHF), systolic
* Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), with acute exacerbation
* History of alcohol abuse
* Recurrent left pleural effusion
* Diabetes mellitus type II

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing albuterol and ipratropium for COPD
* Weaning down from mechanical ventilation to a PEEP of 5 and FiO2 of 40%
* Stopping azithromycin and vancomycin, and continuing ceftriaxone for CAP
* Holding hydralazine due to hypertension
* Monitoring for recurrent left pleural effusion
* Re-checking B12 levels
* Obtaining another Hct this evening and then q12hrs, and transfusing if Hct drops below 21
* Trending coagulopathy and avoiding medications that worsen it
* Continuing to check lytes

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure due to worsening COPD
* Cardiac arrhythmias due to atrial fibrillation
* Sepsis due to bacterial pneumonia
* Acute kidney injury due to hypovolemia and/or sepsis
* Hepatic dysfunction due to possible component of alcohol cardiomyopathy and/or malnutrition
* Thrombocytopenia due to new onset or worsening liver function
* Coagulopathy due to elevated INR and possible malnutrition
* Recurrent left pleural effusion due to underlying chronic heart failure

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the plan of care accordingly to prevent or mitigate these potential complications.

 likely CHF exacerbation and CAP

Summary:

The patient is a 59-year-old male admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a history of systolic chronic heart failure (CHF), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation (AFIB), and alcohol abuse. He was admitted with bradycardia and acute on chronic CHF, initially managed with fluid resulting in worsening heart failure. He was intubated due to worsening respiratory status and is currently on mechanical ventilation.

The patient has been diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), acute respiratory failure, and anemia. He is receiving antibiotics for CAP, and his creatinine level is trending down. His hematocrit is currently 23.8, and he will be transfused if it drops below 21.

The patient's medications include fentanyl, midazolam, haloperidol, metoprolol, albuterol, ipratropium, and ceftriaxone. He is also receiving Lasix bolus and gtt for diuresis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he is at risk of developing further respiratory failure, particularly with the presence of CAP and chronic lung disease.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac status is unstable, and he is at risk of developing further cardiac complications, including cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiogenic shock.
3. Infection: The patient has a diagnosis of CAP, and there is a risk of developing further infections, particularly with the presence of a central line and urinary catheter.
4. Bleeding: The patient has a diagnosis of thrombocytopenia, and he is at risk of bleeding, particularly with the presence of a central line and the use of anticoagulant medications.
5. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient has a diagnosis of hyponatremia and hypochloremia, and there is a risk of developing further electrolyte imbalances, particularly with the use of diuretics and antibiotics.
6. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is currently 1.5, and there is a risk of developing further renal failure, particularly with the presence of underlying chronic kidney disease and the use of nephrotoxic medications.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of chronic liver disease, and there is a risk of developing further gastrointestinal complications, including bleeding, perforation, and liver failure.

   with fluid resulting in worsening heart failure transferred to MICU for
   hypoxia.
   .
   # Dyspnea / Hypoxia
 likely CHF exacerbation and CAP
   - will continue albuterol and ipratropium
   - pt was intubated yesterday secondary to worsening respiratory status
   (now on CMV with PEEP of 10 and FiO2 50%)
 will attempt to wean down
   to a PEEP of 5 and a FiO2 of 40%
   - UOP was low earlier in the day yesterday; picked up when he was given
   a bolus of fluid for hypotension
   - for his CAP, the patient is on ceftriaxone, azithromycin and vanco
   (given hx of MRSA)
 will stop azithromycin and vancomyin and just keep
   ceftriaxone until sensitivites are back
   .
   # Systolic CHF
   - unclear etiology (per cards, possibly some component of alcohol
   cardiomyopathy and possibly some tachy-myopathy)
   - continue metoprolol; possibly start him on an ACEi
 hold hydralazine

s hypertension
   - pt
s [**Name Prefix (Prefixes) **] [**Last Name (Prefixes) 9533**] was held
   .

   - MVI, thiamine, folate

   - F/u social work recs

 was tapped in [**4-5**]
   - CXR today basically unchanged from yesterday
 continue to monitor
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation

   - will increase metoprolol to 50 mg TID
 will hold off on restarting

   - pt not on coumadin per personal preference

   # ARF:

   after a fluid bolus
   - continue to monitor UOP, BUN, and Cr
   .
   # Anemia
   - Hct dropped some yesterday and patient was given a unit of blood
   - will obtain another Hct this pm and then q12hrs
 transfuse if Hct

   - Guaiac stools
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male with a complex medical history, including systolic chronic heart failure (CHF), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation (AF), and alcohol abuse. He was admitted to the ICU with bradycardia and acute on chronic CHF, and was intubated due to worsening respiratory status.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 10 and FiO2 of 50%. He has a respiratory rate of 13 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 98%.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has atrial fibrillation with an elevated heart rate. His blood pressure is 112/67 mmHg, and his cardiac output is 13.1 L/min.
* Hemodynamic: The patient's central venous pressure (CVP) is 14 mmHg, and his mixed venous oxygen saturation is 80%.
* Renal: The patient's urine output is low, and his creatinine is 1.7 mg/dL.
* Hepatic: The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are abnormal, with an elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase.
* Coagulation: The patient has a prolonged international normalized ratio (INR) and is at risk for bleeding.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current status include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may require further adjustments to his mechanical ventilation settings.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and cardiac output may be affected by his underlying heart disease and medication regimen.
* Renal failure: The patient's low urine output and elevated creatinine levels may indicate acute kidney injury (AKI), which can worsen his overall condition.
* Hepatic dysfunction: The patient's abnormal LFTs may indicate liver damage or dysfunction, which can affect his metabolism and overall health.
* Coagulopathy: The patient's prolonged INR and thrombocytopenia may increase his risk of bleeding complications.
* Sepsis: The patient's pneumonia and elevated white blood cell count may increase his risk of developing sepsis.

Based on the patient's current status and potential complications, the following plan of care is recommended:

* Continue mechanical ventilation with adjustments as needed to maintain optimal respiratory function.
* Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely, and consider adjusting his medication regimen to optimize his heart function.
* Continue to monitor the patient's renal function, and consider dialysis if his condition worsens.
* Monitor the patient's liver function, and consider further evaluation if his LFTs remain abnormal.
* Monitor the patient's coagulation status, and consider further evaluation if his INR remains prolonged.
* Consider further evaluation and treatment for the patient's pneumonia, including antibiotics and bronchoscopy.
* Continue to monitor the patient's overall condition, and consider further evaluation and treatment as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-inch tall individual with atrial fibrillation (AF), acute respiratory failure, cardiomyopathy, anemia, pneumonia, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with acute exacerbation. They have a history of heart failure, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, atrial fibrillation, and alcohol abuse.

The patient's vital signs over the past 24 hours are as follows:

* Temperature: 37C (98.6F) to 35.8C (96.4F)
* Heart rate: 100 bpm (89-145 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 112/67 mmHg (79-129/96 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 13 inspirations per minute (0-20 inspirations per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 98%
* Heart rhythm: Atrial fibrillation

The patient is receiving multiple medications, including fentanyl, midazolam, haloperidol, and metoprolol. They are also receiving infusions of fentanyl and midazolam.

The patient's laboratory results over the past 24 hours are as follows:

* White blood cell count: 6.7-5.9-5.7 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.0-7.9 g/dL
* Platelet count: 84-78-82 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.7-1.6 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 216-11-0.05 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 1.0 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.5 g/dL
* LDH: 522 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.5 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.8 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 2.6 mg/dL

The patient's respiratory support includes an endotracheal tube, continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) mode, and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's condition include:

* Cardiac arrhythmias, such as ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation, due to atrial fibrillation
* Respiratory failure, including acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), due to pneumonia and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
* Sepsis, including septic shock, due to bacterial pneumonia
* Cardiac failure, including cardiogenic shock, due to cardiomyopathy
* Anemia, including bleeding or bone marrow failure, due to chronic blood loss or bone marrow suppression
* Infection, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), due to prolonged mechanical ventilation
* Gastrointestinal bleeding, including upper gastrointestinal bleeding, due to stress ulcer disease
* DVT, including pulmonary embolism, due to immobility and venous stasis
* Metabolic acidosis, including lactic acidosis, due to hypoperfusion and tissue hypoxia.
